Description: Body sherd (mended from three small fragments) of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; cream slip; interior glazed black with top of lotus flower in added white; exterior: undetermined motif, perhaps a small cluster of short vertical strokes; below, painted decoration consisting of confronted lion and male figure (part of snout, right eye, whiskers and one fang of lion, to right; nose, mouth and lips of male figure, to left).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lamb (and taken up by Lemos) erroneously describes the lion as a goat, but a) the fang and the whiskers are not goat-related features, and b) whilst goats are the typical animal portrayed on Chian Wild Goat Style vases, they become much rarer and then disappear from the Chian repertoire in the following Mature Animal Style. They are non-existent in the later Grand Style.
